results.title: Germany’s Far Right Reunified, Too, Making It Much Stronger
results.abstract: Thirty years after Germany came back together, the former East has become the stronghold of a once-marginalized movement that now sits in Parliament.

results.title: Contact Tracing, Key to Reining In the Virus, Falls Flat in the West
results.abstract: Tracing is seen as a vital tool to avoid lockdowns and open economies, but that requires a robust system, widespread rapid testing and public trust. All are lacking in the West.

multimedia.caption: In Paris in August. Tracing operations in Europe have left the public in the dark about their exposure to the coronavirus.

results.abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the president of the European Commission agreed that the two sides shared enough common ground to aim for a final settlement.

results.title: India’s Covid-19 Death Toll Passes 100,000
results.abstract: Only the United States and Brazil have reported more deaths from the coronavirus. Despite its climbing numbers, India plans to lift more restrictions.

results.title: After 30 Years, East and West Germans Wonder: How United Are We?
results.abstract: With Germany now an established, reunified democracy, it is taking stock of what is working and what still needs work, especially as the economy continues to lag in the former East.

results.title: 30 Years After Reunification, Old German-German Border Is a Green Oasis
results.abstract: Crossing the militarized border that split Germany into east and west once meant risking death. Now? It’s a literal walk in the park.

results.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s speech addressed a deep-rooted problem in French society: its enduring difficulty to integrate significant parts of its large, nonwhite, Muslim population of immigrants and their descendants.

results.title: A Black Belgian Student Saw a White Fraternity as His Ticket. It Was His Death.
results.abstract: Sanda Dia’s death after an initiation ritual was regarded as a tragic accident. Newly released videos and photos have made it a symbol of growing intolerance.
results.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Steven Erlanger

multimedia.caption: Sanda Dia in a family photo. Joining the almost all-white club, he told his brother, meant that “when you leave school they will trust you a lot faster.”

results.title: Black Germans Say It’s Time to Look Inward
results.abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement saw shows of solidarity around the world this summer. In Germany, some feel there is a reluctance to acknowledge more local problems.

multimedia.caption: At least 15,000 people gathered to protest racism in Berlin on June 6. But people who work on anti-racism initiatives said the crowds seemed more eager to show solidarity with the United States than to self-reflect.
multimedia.copyright: Mustafah Abdulaziz/National Geographic Society’s Emergency Fund for Journalists

results.title: Six Months in the Life of a Locked-Down Theater
results.abstract: Britain’s National Theater hopes to reopen in October after being closed for more than 200 days. But even with the shutters down, it’s been an eventful and emotional time for its staff.
